methods.javadoc:
Imports key bindings from a location selected by the user.

If there is a problem reading the data then the user will be shown an error dialog. @param inputStream the input stream from which to read options @return An options object that is composed of key binding names and their associated keystrokes.
methods.name: createOptionsforKeybindings
methods.comment:
Imports key bindings from a location selected by the user.
 
 If there is a problem reading the data then the user will be shown an
 error dialog.

params.name: inputStream
params.comment: the input stream from which to read options

return.comment:
An options object that is composed of key binding names and their
         associated keystrokes.

methods.javadoc:
Saves the key bindings from the provided options object to a file chosen by the user.

If there is a problem writing the data then the user will be shown an error dialog. @param keyBindingOptions The options that contains key binding data.
methods.name: exportKeyBindings
methods.comment:
Saves the key bindings from the provided options object to a file chosen
 by the user.
 
 If there is a problem writing the data then the user will be shown an
 error dialog.

params.name: keyBindingOptions
params.comment: The options that contains key binding data.

methods.javadoc:
A convenience method to register the given action with the given component. This is not usually done, as the action system is usually managed by the application's tool. However, for actions that are not registered with a tool, they can instead be bound to a component, hence this method.

The given action must have a keystroke assigned, or this method will do nothing. @param component the component to which the given action will be bound @param action the action to bind
methods.name: registerAction
methods.comment:
A convenience method to register the given action with the given
 component. This is not usually done, as the action system is usually
 managed by the application's tool. However, for actions that are not
 registered with a tool, they can instead be bound to a component, hence
 this method.
 
 The given action must have a keystroke assigned, or this method will do
 nothing.

params.name: component
params.comment: the component to which the given action will be bound

params.name: action
params.comment: the action to bind

methods.javadoc:
A convenience method to register the given action with the given component. This is not usually done, as the action system is usually managed by the application's tool. However, for actions that are not registered with a tool, they can instead be bound to a component, hence this method.

The given action must have a keystroke assigned, or this method will do nothing.

A typical use-case is to register an existing docking action with a text component, which is needed because the docking key event processing will not execute docking- registered actions if a text component has focus. @param component the component to which the given action will be bound @param action the action to bind @param contextProvider the provider of the context
methods.name: registerAction
methods.comment:
A convenience method to register the given action with the given
 component. This is not usually done, as the action system is usually
 managed by the application's tool. However, for actions that are not
 registered with a tool, they can instead be bound to a component, hence
 this method.
 
 The given action must have a keystroke assigned, or this method will do
 nothing.
 
 
 A typical use-case is to register an existing docking action with a text
 component, which is needed because the docking key event processing will
 not execute docking- registered actions if a text component has focus.

params.name: component
params.comment: the component to which the given action will be bound

params.name: action
params.comment: the action to bind

params.name: contextProvider
params.comment: the provider of the context

methods.javadoc:
A convenience method to register the given action with the given component. This is not usually done, as the action system is usually managed by the application's tool. However, for actions that are not registered with a tool, they can instead be bound to a component, hence this method.

The given action must have a keystroke assigned, or this method will do nothing.

A typical use-case is to register an existing docking action with a text component, which is needed because the docking key event processing will not execute docking- registered actions if a text component has focus. @param component the component to which the given action will be bound @param action the action to bind @param contextProvider the provider of the context @param focusCondition see {@link JComponent} for more info; the default is usually {@link JComponent#WHEN_FOCUSED}
methods.name: registerAction
methods.comment:
A convenience method to register the given action with the given
 component. This is not usually done, as the action system is usually
 managed by the application's tool. However, for actions that are not
 registered with a tool, they can instead be bound to a component, hence
 this method.
 
 The given action must have a keystroke assigned, or this method will do
 nothing.
 
 
 A typical use-case is to register an existing docking action with a text
 component, which is needed because the docking key event processing will
 not execute docking- registered actions if a text component has focus.

params.name: component
params.comment: the component to which the given action will be bound

params.name: action
params.comment: the action to bind

params.name: contextProvider
params.comment: the provider of the context

params.name: focusCondition
params.comment:
see JComponent for more info; the default
            is usually JComponent#WHEN_FOCUSED

methods.name: registerAction
methods.comment:
Registers the given action with the given key binding on the given
 component.

params.name: component
params.comment: the component to which the action will be registered

params.name: keyStroke
params.comment: the keystroke for to which the action will be bound

params.name: action
params.comment: the action to execute when the given keystroke is triggered

params.name: focusCondition

methods.javadoc:
Allows the client to clear Java key bindings when the client is creating a docking 
 action.   Without this call, any actions bound to the given component will prevent an
 action with the same key binding from firing.  This is useful when your
 application is using tool-level key bindings that share the same
 keystroke as a built-in Java action, such as Ctrl-C for the copy action.
@param component the component for which to clear the key binding
@param action the action from which to get the key binding
methods.name: clearKeyBinding
methods.comment:
Allows the client to clear Java key bindings when the client is creating a docking 
 action.   Without this call, any actions bound to the given component will prevent an
 action with the same key binding from firing.  This is useful when your
 application is using tool-level key bindings that share the same
 keystroke as a built-in Java action, such as Ctrl-C for the copy action.

params.name: component
params.comment: the component for which to clear the key binding

params.name: action
params.comment: the action from which to get the key binding

methods.name: clearKeyBinding
methods.comment:
Allows clients to clear Java key bindings. This is useful when your
 application is using tool-level key bindings that share the same
 keystroke as a built-in Java action, such as Ctrl-C for the copy action.
 
 Note: this method clears the key binding for the 
 JComponent#WHEN_FOCUSED and 
 JComponent#WHEN_ANCESTOR_OF_FOCUSED_COMPONENT focus conditions.

params.name: component
params.comment: the component for which to clear the key binding

params.name: keyStroke
params.comment: the keystroke of the binding to be cleared

methods.name: clearKeyBinding
methods.comment:
Allows clients to clear Java key bindings. This is useful when your
 application is using tool-level key bindings that share the same
 keystroke as a built-in Java action, such as Ctrl-C for the copy action.

params.name: component
params.comment: the component for which to clear the key binding

params.name: keyStroke
params.comment: the keystroke of the binding to be cleared

params.name: focusCondition
params.comment:
the particular focus condition under which the
            given keystroke is used (see
            JComponent#getInputMap(int)).

methods.name: getAction
methods.comment:
Returns the registered action for the given keystroke, or null of no
 action is bound to that keystroke.

params.name: component
params.comment: the component for which to check the binding

params.name: keyStroke
params.comment: the keystroke for which to find a bound action

params.name: focusCondition
params.comment:
the focus condition under which to check for the
            binding (JComponent#getInputMap(int))

return.comment:
the action registered to the given keystroke, or null of no
         action is registered

methods.javadoc:
A utility method to get all key binding actions. This method will only return actions that support {@link KeyBindingType key bindings}.

The mapping returned provides a list of items because it is possible for there to exists multiple actions with the same name and owner. (This can happen when multiple copies of a component provider are shown, each with their own set of actions that share the same name.) @param tool the tool containing the actions @return the actions mapped by their full name (e.g., 'Name (OwnerName)')
methods.name: getAllActionsByFullName
methods.comment:
A utility method to get all key binding actions.  This method will 
 only return actions that support KeyBindingType.
 
 The mapping returned provides a list of items because it is possible for there to 
 exists multiple actions with the same name and owner.  (This can happen when multiple copies
 of a component provider are shown, each with their own set of actions that share the
 same name.)

params.name: tool
params.comment: the tool containing the actions

return.comment: the actions mapped by their full name (e.g., 'Name (OwnerName)')

methods.name: getKeyBindingActionsForOwner
methods.comment:
A utility method to get all key binding actions that have the given owner.  
 This method will remove duplicate actions and will only return actions 
 that support KeyBindingType.

params.name: tool
params.comment: the tool containing the actions

params.name: owner
params.comment: the action owner name

methods.name: getActions
methods.comment: Returns all actions that match the given owner and name

params.name: allActions
params.comment: the universe of actions

params.name: owner
params.comment: the owner

params.name: name
params.comment: the name

methods.name: adaptDockingActionToNonContextAction
methods.comment:
Takes the existing docking action and allows it to be registered with
 Swing components
 
 
 The new action will not be correctly wired into the Docking Action
 Context system. This means that the given docking action should not rely
 on DockingAction#isEnabledForContext(docking.ActionContext) to
 work when called from the Swing widget.

params.name: action
params.comment: the docking action to adapt to a Swing Action

methods.name: assertSameDefaultKeyBindings
methods.comment:
Checks each action in the given collection against the given new action to make sure that
 they share the same default key binding.

params.name: newAction
params.comment: the action to check

params.name: existingActions
params.comment: the actions that have already been checked

methods.name: logDifferentKeyBindingsWarnigMessage
methods.comment:
Logs a warning message for the two given actions to signal that they do not share the
 same default key binding

params.name: newAction
params.comment: the new action

params.name: existingAction
params.comment: the action that has already been validated

params.name: existingDefaultKs
params.comment: the current validated key stroke

methods.name: validateKeyStroke
methods.comment:
Updates the given data with system-independent versions of key modifiers.  For example, 
 the control key will be converted to the command key on the Mac.

params.name: keyStroke
params.comment: the keystroke to validate

methods.javadoc:
Convert the toString() form of the keyStroke.
In Java 1.4.2 & earlier, Ctrl-M is returned as "keyCode CtrlM-P" and we want it to look like: "Ctrl-M".
In Java 1.5.0, Ctrl-M is returned as "ctrl pressed M" and we want it to look like: "Ctrl-M". @param keyStroke the key stroke @return the string value; the empty string if the key stroke is null
methods.name: parseKeyStroke
methods.comment:
Convert the toString() form of the keyStroke.
 In Java 1.4.2  earlier, Ctrl-M is returned as "keyCode CtrlM-P"
 and we want it to look like: "Ctrl-M".
 In Java 1.5.0, Ctrl-M is returned as "ctrl pressed M"
 and we want it to look like: "Ctrl-M".

params.name: keyStroke
params.comment: the key stroke

return.comment: the string value; the empty string if the key stroke is null

methods.javadoc:
Parses the given text into a KeyStroke. This method relies upon {@link KeyStroke#getKeyStroke(String)} for parsing. Before making that call, this method will perform fixup on the given text for added flexibility. For example, the given text may contain spaces or dashes as the separators between parts in the string. Also, the text is converted such that it is not case-sensitive. So, the following example formats are allowed: 
    Alt-F
    alt p
    Ctrl-Alt-Z
    ctrl Z
@param keyStroke @return the new key stroke (as returned by {@link KeyStroke#getKeyStroke(String)}
methods.name: parseKeyStroke
methods.comment:
Parses the given text into a KeyStroke.  This method relies upon 
 KeyStroke#getKeyStroke(String) for parsing.  Before making that call, this method
 will perform fixup on the given text for added flexibility.  For example, the given 
 text may contain spaces or dashes as the separators between parts in the string.  Also, 
 the text is converted such that it is not case-sensitive.  So, the following example 
 formats are allowed:
 
    Alt-F
    alt p
    Ctrl-Alt-Z
    ctrl Z

return.comment: the new key stroke (as returned by  KeyStroke#getKeyStroke(String)

name: KeyBindingUtils
comment:
A class to provide utilities for system key bindings, such as importing and
 exporting key binding configurations.
